comment._content: Wonderful! I wonder what their message says -

comment.author: 55597723@N02
comment._content: Nice Photo. I've never seen anything like it ( they all look great )

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: MDX it doesn't say anything, they are posing as though they were sending semaphore signals but that requires two flags whereas they each have just the one.  Ideally when sending semaphore the signaller turned his back to the receiver to avoid confusion as to which was left and which was right.  The guy with the poignard is striking a right regal pose once again, I wonder was he ever as good as he thought he was???  Carol, we were the Limerick branch of na Fianna, enough said???

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] What is a poignard? p.s. Really made me laugh with "We were the Limerick branch of na Fianna, enough said???" This is because I asked swordscookie (who was in Fianna Éireann / Na Fianna when he was a child) if he would like to have had access to swords...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: A poignard was a short sword and mostly carried by dandy's who didn't want to be trailing a great meat cleaver about when in their finery!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Looking at it again and the memory slowly coming back the front row are spelling A<B<C<D the right rear spells E but the others are just trying to confuse the enemy!
